August 20, 1989: Fiction
THE RUSSIA HOUSE, by John le Carr√©. (Knopf, $19.95.) Espionage changes its ways
as glasnost begins to rust the Iron Curtain.
POLAR STAR, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $19.95.)  Russian and American
teams investigate the mysterious movements of a Soviet ship in northern Pacific waters.
THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $18.95.) The tensions and cultural
bonds shared by Chinese-American women and their immigrant mothers.
BLESSINGS, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A lawyer's romantic past catches up
with her on the eve of her marriage and the trial of her most important case.
WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster,
$19.95.) The murder of a gossip writer creates a storm in New York's high-fashion
world.
RED PHOENIX, by Larry Bond. (Warner, $19.95.) Three American servicemen and the
roles they play in a second Korean war.
KNIGHT IN SHINING ARMOR, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $17.95.) A 20th-century
American woman finds love though an encounter with a 16th-century English nobleman.
JOURNEY, by James Michener.  (Random House, $16.95.) The 1897 trek of four British
aristocrats and an Irish manservant across Canada to reach the Klondike gold fields.
THE TEMPLE OF MY FAMILIAR, by Alice Walker. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich,
$19.95.) The relations of the species, races and sexes through the past 5,000 centuries.
THE NEGOTIATOR, by Frederick Forsyth. (Bantam, $19.95.) An American expatriate
tries to thwart terrorists' attempts to prevent the signing of a disarmament pact.
WIN, LOSE OR DIE, by John Gardner. (Putnam, $13.95.) James Bond takes on
terrorists during a British, Russian and American naval exercise.
MURDER AT THE KENNEDY CENTER, by Margaret Truman.  (Random House,
&17.95.) Intrigue and passion surround the mysterious death of the aide to a
Presidential candidate.
TALKING GOD, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) Two New Mexican
policemen pursue a mystery involving valuable Indian ceremonial masks.
DAY OF THE CHEETAH, by Dale Brown (Fine, $18.95.) America's most advanced
weapon falls into the hands of a pilot who is a K.G.B. mole.
PRINCE OF THE BLOOD, by Raymond E. Feist.  (Foundation/Doubleday, $18.95.)
Intrigue and rebellion wrack the fantasy land of Kesh.
August 20, 1989
Non-Fiction
ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert
Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters.
IT'S ALWAYS SOMETHING, by Gilda Radner. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The
late comedian's memoir describes her battle with ovarian cancer.
A WOMAN NAMED JACKIE, by C. David Heymann. (Lyle Stuart, $21.95.) A
biography of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.
A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A
scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe.
THE GOOD TIMES, by Russell Baker. (Morrow, $19.95.) The New York Times
columnist recalls his experiences from Baltimore newsboy to Washington
correspondent during the 50's and 60's.
FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus &
Giroux, $22.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict as observed by a New York times
correspondent over the past decade.
SUMMER OF '49, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $21.95.) The year the Boston
Red Sox and the New York Yankees battled to the last game for the American
League pennant.
KING OF THE NIGHT, by Laurence Leamer. (Morrow, $19.95.) A biography of the
television talk-show host Johnny Carson.
PERSONAL FOULS, by Peter Golenbock.  (Carroll & Graf, $18.95.) An
investigative account of the basketball program at North Carolina State University.
DAVE BARRY SLEPT HERE, by Dave Barry.  (Random House, $12.95.)  A
humorist's account of American history.
LOVE AND MARRIAGE, by Bill Cosby. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Observations on the
elations and frustrations of romantic relationships.
GREAT PLAINS, by Ian Frazier. (Farrar, Straus, & Giroux, $17.95.) The history
and legends of the American prairies depicted by a visitor from the East.
THE ANDY WARHOL DIARIES, edited by Pat Hackett. (Warner, $29.95.)
Observations and opinions dictated by the artist and celebrity from 1976 to 1987.
CITIZENS, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $29.95.) A history of the French
Revolution.
RUNNING THE AMAZON, by Joe Kane. (Knopf, $19.95.) The journal of a trek
along the length of the Western Hemisphere's longest river.
